name: market for hard coal | hard coal | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/2125/documentation

This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.;This is the market for  'hard coal', in the geography of South Africa.;This dataset describes the average transport for the consumption of South African thermal coal, both for domestic consumption and for export. The market includes domestic coal sold on the open market (accounting for 37% of domestic coal sales, 26% of which are to Eskom for power generation), coal directly supplied to power stations via converyors from tied collieries (38% of domestic coal sales) and coal used by SASOL in their own operations for production of synthetic fuels and chemicals (22% of domestic coal sales). The remaining 3% of domestic sales is of metallurgical coal. The dataset also covers 35% of South Africa's coal exports (representing exports to countries other than India and Europe, as these are covered by their own market datasets). As such this market process is comprised of 87% domestic sales and 13% export sales and accounts for the sale of 210 million tonnes in 2014 (domestic and export sales extracted from DMR (2015a). Geographical breakdown in exports extracted from ITC (2017) and breakdown in domestic sales from DMR (2015b). An estimate of dust from transport and loading/unloading operations is included, with average coal losses assumed to equal particulate losses. Average emissions to water due to leaching from coal heaps at storage is estimated from the literature. Reference(s): ITC (2017) Trademap Database, Available at: http://www.trademap.org/. (Accessed July 2017). DMR (2015a) Mineral Production and Sales and Mining Labour Statistics Tables 1993 - 2014, Department of Mineral Resources. Available at: http://www.dmr.gov.za/ (Accessed: March 2017); DMR (2015b) South Africa's Mineral Industry 2014/15, Department of Mineral Resources. Available at: http://www.dmr.gov.za/. (Accessed June 2017).;The market includes domestic coal sold on the open market (accounting for 37% of domestic coal sales, 26% of which are to Eskom for power generation), coal directly supplied to power stations via converyors from tied collieries (38% of domestic coal sales) and coal used by SASOL in their own operations for production of synthetic fuels and chemicals (22% of domestic coal sales). The remaining 3% of domestic sales is of metallurgical coal. The dataset also covers 35% of South Africa's coal exports (representing exports to countries other than India and Europe, as these are covered by their own market datasets). As such this market process is comprised of 87% domestic sales and 13% export sales and accounts for the sale of 210 million tonnes in 2014 (domestic and export sales extracted from DMR (2015a). Geographical breakdown in exports extracted from ITC (2017) and breakdown in domestic sales from DMR (2015b). Reference(s): ITC (2017) Trademap Database, Available at: http://www.trademap.org/. (Accessed July 2017). DMR (2015a) Mineral Production and Sales and Mining Labour Statistics Tables 1993 - 2014, Department of Mineral Resources. Available at: http://www.dmr.gov.za/ (Accessed: March 2017); DMR (2015b) South Africa's Mineral Industry 2014/15, Department of Mineral Resources. Available at: http://www.dmr.gov.za/. (Accessed June 2017).

Starting at the gate of the hard coal mine, this dataset includes the transport, re-loading and storage within the producing/exporting country.

This activity ends at the consumer (for domestic sales) and up to the point of leaving South Africa (for export sales). 
 Losses are included.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/05:Mining of coal and lignite/051:Mining of hard coal/0510:Mining of hard coal

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The trade volumes are for 2014, acquired from a Department of Mineral Resources publication (DMR, 2015) and export statistics from ITC (2017). Reference(s):  ITC (2017) Trademap Database, Available at: http://www.trademap.org/. (Accessed July 2017); DMR (2015) Operating and Developing Coal Mines in the Republic of South Africa 2015, Department of Mineral Resources. Available at: http://www.dmr.gov.za/. (Accessed: June 2017)
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: South African values; not applicable worldwide.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Coal sold locally is transported predominantly by road to end-users, with some transported by rail; while the export coal is transported by rail to the South Africa's primary coal export terminal (Ricards Bay Coal Terminal, KwaZulu-Natal).
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Trade volumes are for 2014 and are obtained from South Africa's Department of Mineral Resources (DMR, 2015a and 2015b) and from the International Trade Centre (ITC, 2017). The market consists of 13% export sales and 87% local sales (market excludes coal exported to Europe and India). The distance that the coal is railed to the Richards Bay coal terminal on the East Coast of South Africa for export is calculated from a weighted average of the distance from the respective coalfields producing coal for export and the production volumes of export grade coal from each coalfield. The distances were estimated using Google Maps, while the production volumes were sourced from industry data. The Richard's Bay Coal Terminal (RBCT) accounts for  95% of South Africa's coal exports. For the local utility sales fraction, coal transport distances and modes (road and rail) is calculated from reports on Eskom's road to rail migration programme (Engineering News, 2015). Coal losses are assumed to arise only from particulate emissions to air, with particulate emissions from loading/unloading, transit and stockpiles estimated according to Chadwick et al., (1987) and NPI (2012).  Due to a lack information, emissions to ground water (arising from leachate from coal stockpiles) have not been updated and use the same generic estimates as the other ecoivent coal mining datasets (i.e. they are  estimated with high uncertainty according to Dones et al. (2007), based on three studies conducted in the 1980s by Kok et al. (1989), ORNL (1980) and Zahner (1980)).  Conveyor belt usage was calculated on the basis of publically available data reported by the Richards Bay Coal Terminal (RBCT, 2014). 
Reference(s):  ITC (2017) Trademap Database, Available at: http://www.trademap.org/ (Accessed July 2017); DMR (2015a) Mineral Production and Sales and Mining Labour Statistics Tables 1993 - 2014, Department of Mineral Resources. Available at: http://www.dmr.gov.za/ (Accessed: March 2017); DMR (2015b) South Africa's Mineral Industry 2014/15, Department of Mineral Resources. Available at: http://www.dmr.gov.za/. (Accessed June 2017);  DMR (2015) Operating and Developing Coal Mines in the Republic of South Africa 2015, Department of Mineral Resources. Available at: http://www.dmr.gov.za/. (Accessed: June 2017); Chadwick, M. J., Highton, N.H. and Lindman, N. (1987) Environmental Impacts of Coal Mining and Utilization: A Complete Revision of Environmental Implications of Expanded Coal Utilization; NPI (2012) Emission Estimation Technique Manual for Mining. Version 3.1, National Pollution Inventory, Available at: http://www.npi.gov.au/system/files/resources/7e04163a-12ba-6864-d19a-f57d960aae58/files/mining.pdf. (Accessed on: July 2017); RBCT (2014) Company Website, Richards Bay Coal Terminal. Available at: https://www.rbct.co.za/faq-6/. (Accessed July 2017); Engineering News (2015) Eskom aiming to slash truck-delivered coal as it seeks cost, other benefits. Available at: http://www.engineeringnews.co.za/print-version/eskom-continues-focus-on-reducing-coal-road-haulage-volumes-2015-07-24 (Accessed: June 2017); Dones, R., Bauer, C., Röder, A. (2007) Kohle. In: Dones, R. (Ed.) et al., Sachbilanzen von Energiesystemen: Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von Energiesystemen und den Einbezug von Energiesystemen in Ökobilanzen für die Schweiz. Final report ecoinvent No. 6-VI, Paul Scherrer Institut Villigen, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.; Kok A., Bolt N., Jelgersma R. (1989) Spontaneous heating and stockpiling losses of coal. In: Kema Scientific & Technical Reports 7 (2):63-89.; ORNL (1980) A Methodology and a Preliminary Data Base for Examining the Health Risks of Electricity Generation from Uranium and Coal Fuels. Oak Ridge, USA.; Zahner Ph. (1985) Le stockage du charbon et du coke en plein air: pollution et protection des eaux. Les cahiers de l'environnement No 38, OFPE, Bern. .

flow.name: hard coal
flow.category: B:Mining and quarrying/05:Mining of coal and lignite/051:Mining of hard coal/0510:Mining of hard coal

exchanges.description:
Estimated value not geography specific (generic value used in other ecoinvent coal market datasets). This represents the leaching of Nickel to ground water during storage in open stockpiles. For a lack of more recent data this value is an estimation according to Dones et al. (2007) based on three studies conducted in the 1980ies by Kok et al. (1989), ORNL (1980) and Zahner (1980). 500 liters of leachate per m2 of storage area are assumed for an average storage time of two months, an average pile height of 6m and a bulk density of 700kg/m3. High uncertainty for estimates of leachate emissions has to be assumed.
Reference(s): Dones, R., Bauer, C., Röder, A. (2007) Kohle. In: Dones, R. (Ed.) et al., Sachbilanzen
von Energiesystemen: Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von
Energiesystemen und den Einbezug von Energiesystemen in Ökobilanzen für die
Schweiz. Final report ecoinvent No. 6-VI, Paul Scherrer Institut Villigen, Swiss Centre
for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
Kok A., Bolt N., Jelgersma R. (1989) Spontaneous heating and stockpiling losses of
coal. In: Kema Scientific & Technical Reports 7 (2):63-89.
ORNL (1980) A Methodology and a Preliminary Data Base for Examining the Health
Risks of Electricity Generation from Uranium and Coal Fuels. Oak Ridge, USA.
Zahner Ph. (1985) Le stockage du charbon et du coke en plein air: pollution et
protection des eaux. Les cahiers de l'environnement No 38, OFPE, Bern.

Estimated value not geography specific (generic value used in other ecoinvent coal market datasets). This represents the DOC due to leaching to ground water during storage in open stockpiles. For a lack of more recent data this value is Calculated as equal to TOC. Value for TOC according to Dones et al. (2007). 500 liters of leachate per m2 of storage area are assumed for an average storage time of two months, an average pile height of 6m and a bulk density of 700kg/m3. High uncertainty for estimates of leachate emissions has to be assumed.
Reference(s): Dones, R., Bauer, C., Röder, A. (2007) Kohle. In: Dones, R. (Ed.) et al., Sachbilanzen
von Energiesystemen: Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von
Energiesystemen und den Einbezug von Energiesystemen in Ökobilanzen für die
Schweiz. Final report ecoinvent No. 6-VI, Paul Scherrer Institut Villigen, Swiss Centre
for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.

exchanges.description:
Estimated value not geography specific (generic value used in other ecoinvent coal market datasets). This represents the leaching of Arsenic to ground water during storage in open stockpiles. For a lack of more recent data this value is an estimation according to Dones et al. (2007) based on three studies conducted in the 1980ies by Kok et al. (1989), ORNL (1980) and Zahner (1980). 500 liters of leachate per m2 of storage area are assumed for an average storage time of two months, an average pile height of 6m and a bulk density of 700kg/m3. High uncertainty for estimates of leachate emissions has to be assumed.
Reference(s): Dones, R., Bauer, C., Röder, A. (2007) Kohle. In: Dones, R. (Ed.) et al., Sachbilanzen
von Energiesystemen: Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von
Energiesystemen und den Einbezug von Energiesystemen in Ökobilanzen für die
Schweiz. Final report ecoinvent No. 6-VI, Paul Scherrer Institut Villigen, Swiss Centre
for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
Kok A., Bolt N., Jelgersma R. (1989) Spontaneous heating and stockpiling losses of
coal. In: Kema Scientific & Technical Reports 7 (2):63-89.
ORNL (1980) A Methodology and a Preliminary Data Base for Examining the Health
Risks of Electricity Generation from Uranium and Coal Fuels. Oak Ridge, USA.
Zahner Ph. (1985) Le stockage du charbon et du coke en plein air: pollution et
protection des eaux. Les cahiers de l'environnement No 38, OFPE, Bern.

25% of coal sold on the domestic market transported via rail  (figure for Eskom applied to all domestic coal), with the balance transported by road. Average rail distance for coal supplied to Eskom is 140 km (distance of the road to rail migration network), whilst that for other domestic coal is assumed to be 800 km. All export coal is transported by rail to the Richard's Bay Coal Terminal (RBCT), which handles 95% of coal exports from South Africa. The distance to the port is calculated from a weighted average of the average distance from the respective coalfields producing coal for export and the production volumes of export grade coal from each coalfield. The distances were estimated using Google Maps, while the production volumes were sourced from industry data.

High uncertainty for estimates of leachate emissions has to be assumed.

75% of coal sold on the domestic market transported via road  (figure for Eskom), with the balance transported by rail. Average road distance of 300 km (figure for Eskom) with coal transported in 62 tonne trucks.

for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.

coal. In: Kema Scientific & Technical Reports 7 (2):63-89.
ORNL (1980) A Methodology and a Preliminary Data Base for Examining the Health
Risks of Electricity Generation from Uranium and Coal Fuels. Oak Ridge, USA.
Zahner Ph. (1985) Le stockage du charbon et du coke en plein air: pollution et
protection des eaux. Les cahiers de l'environnement No 38, OFPE, Bern.

Estimated value not geography specific (generic value used in other ecoinvent coal market datasets). This represents the TOC due to leaching to ground water during storage in open stockpiles. For a lack of more recent data this value is "Calculated by default as TOC (gC) = COD/2.7 (COD measured in g O2). Should more correctly be calculated from the carbon content of the specified emissions to water." according to Dones et al. (2007). 500 liters of leachate per m2 of storage area are assumed for an average storage time of two months, an average pile height of 6m and a bulk density of 700kg/m3. High uncertainty for estimates of leachate emissions has to be assumed.
Reference(s): Dones, R., Bauer, C., Röder, A. (2007) Kohle. In: Dones, R. (Ed.) et al., Sachbilanzen
von Energiesystemen: Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von
Energiesystemen und den Einbezug von Energiesystemen in Ökobilanzen für die
Schweiz. Final report ecoinvent No. 6-VI, Paul Scherrer Institut Villigen, Swiss Centre
for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.

Estimated value not geography specific (generic value used in other ecoinvent coal market datasets). This represents the leaching of Selenium to ground water during storage in open stockpiles. For a lack of more recent data this value is an estimation according to Dones et al. (2007) based on three studies conducted in the 1980ies by Kok et al. (1989), ORNL (1980) and Zahner (1980). 500 liters of leachate per m2 of storage area are assumed for an average storage time of two months, an average pile height of 6m and a bulk density of 700kg/m3. High uncertainty for estimates of leachate emissions has to be assumed.

von Energiesystemen: Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von

Schweiz. Final report ecoinvent No. 6-VI, Paul Scherrer Institut Villigen, Swiss Centre
for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
Kok A., Bolt N., Jelgersma R. (1989) Spontaneous heating and stockpiling losses of
coal. In: Kema Scientific & Technical Reports 7 (2):63-89.
ORNL (1980) A Methodology and a Preliminary Data Base for Examining the Health
Risks of Electricity Generation from Uranium and Coal Fuels. Oak Ridge, USA.
Zahner Ph. (1985) Le stockage du charbon et du coke en plein air: pollution et
protection des eaux. Les cahiers de l'environnement No 38, OFPE, Bern.

Conveyor belt use associated with coal handling estimated from that of the Richards Bay Coal Terminal. As at 2014, RBCT reported the use of 56km belting and structures with a capacity of 90 million tonnes coal per year. This market dataset account for 13% of South Africa's total coal exports. Source: RBCT (2014) Company Website, Richards Bay Coal Terminal. Available at: https://www.rbct.co.za/faq-6/. (Accessed July 2017).

Estimated value not geography specific (generic value used in other ecoinvent coal market datasets). This represents the leaching of Lead to ground water during storage in open stockpiles. Due to a lack of site specific data, this value is based on emission factors for loading, unloading, transit and stockpiling stages. Emission factors for loading, unloading and transit via rail and ship from Chadwick, M. J., Highton, N.H. and Lindman, N. (1987) Environmental Impacts of Coal Mining and Utilization: A Complete Revision of Environmental Implications of Expanded Coal Utilization. Emissions factors for loading/unloading of stockpile and during stockpiling due to wind erosion from NPI (2012) Emission Estimation Technique Manual for Mining. Version 3.1, National Pollution Inventory, Available at: http://www.npi.gov.au/system/files/resources/7e04163a-12ba-6864-d19a-f57d960aae58/files/mining.pdf. (Accessed on: July 2017).
